column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=FLORIDA WATER. — This perfume, which, of course, is not
#Text=protected with a proprietary name, is one of exceedingly popular
#Text=character in America, and, to a smaller extent, in far Eastern
#Text=countries that import it.
#Text=It is, in the United States, largely what
#Text=lavender water is in England.
#Text=It is a toilet perfume somewhat
#Text=resembling a mixture of lavender water and eau de Cologne,
#Text=rounded off with one or more of the following bodies ; cassia oil
#Text=(or cinnamon oil, or cinnamic aldehyde) ; clove oil (or pimento
#Text=oil, bay oil, or eugenol) ; and lemongrass oil.
#Text=FOIN-COUPE. — This popular type of perfume is supposed
#Text=to reproduce the odour of new-mown hay.
#Text=It is invariably based
#Text=on coumarin, modified by lavender, bergamot, and other perfumes,
#Text=according to the exact note the perfumer wishes to give to his
#Text=product.
#Text=The odour of true new-mown hay is due more to the
#Text=sweet-scented grass known as Anthoxanthum odoratum than to
#Text=any other grass, although many others contribute to it.
#Text=Several
#Text=different types of clover, of course, also add to the fragrance of the
#Text=hayfield odour.
#Text=This odour is probably the result of glucosidal
#Text=decomposition of constituents present in the plants, resulting in
#Text=the formation of a little coumarin.
